Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High-Purity Extraction of PET from Carpet Waste
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project will enable the recycling of valuable materials from complex wastes that today cannot be recovered. The commercial impact from this innovation is to allow for complex waste streams that contain multiple materials, such as carpets and textiles, to serve as the source of raw materials for the manufacture of new goods in a way that is cost advantaged. This gives those businesses that use such raw materials a sustainable alternative and, a lower-cost, efficiently produced material. In this way, there will be significant incentive for the reuse of thousands of tons of material that today either goes to landfills, oceans, or is incinerated for energy- a very low value application. The project will yield an entirely new framework for recycling of complex, multi-component materials.

This project will develop novel technologies for fractionating complex wastes. Multi-component wastes such as carpets and textiles represent upwards of 4% of total landfill volume. Today, there does not exist technology for recovering the high-value materials that are in these wastes. The proposed project intends to develop a new approach using chemical techniques as opposed to simple melt recycling, to enable the value-added recycling of high value polymers from such wastes. Chemical process development will take place in order to take the current status of the technology to a status that is ready for implementation in a pilot plant. The main technical objective is to develop the process for production of consistent, high purity product. Materials such as polyester and nylon currently cannot be separated from natural or cellulosic fibers such as cotton or even heavily cross-linked rubbers as those that are found in carpet. The goals of the research are to develop the proposers' current process for fractionating the nylons and polyesters with an emphasis on achieving high purity products for reuse. To this end, various solution processing techniques will be investigated for exclusion of impurities from end product polymer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF SBIR Phase I funding was provided for the development of Ambercycle’s technology to produce virgin-grade polymers from high-volume mixed wastes such as carpet, apparel, and building materials. In the market there are very few, if any, cost-effective technologies that can separate pure materials from these multi-component wastes. Historically, efforts to recover pure polymers from such wastes have suffered from the inability to produce polymers of sufficient purity and molecular weight. Thus, these materials are often landfilled or burned for energy, representing a massive waste of embodied chemical energy.

Ambercycle develops technologies for the separation of pure polymers out from exactly these types of waste feedstocks. Mixed textile wastes, for example, can be separated into virgin-grade PET, nylons, cotton, etc. using Ambercycle’s process. These materials can be used to make new textiles. The implementation of the process will be to construct a large facility that conducts this process, with the goal to produce hundreds of thousands of tons or more of pure, virgin-grade polymer resins from mixed waste streams.

In order to convert mixed, polymeric, fibrous wastes into price-preferred pure polymers, process development was undergone during the NSF SBIR Phase I project to achieve the following objectives:

1. Production of high-purity polymers from mixed wastes

2. Production of high molecular weight polymers from these wastes

3. High yield of polymer production from the process

During the course of the Phase I project, the technology was taken from a proof-of-concept stage to a well-developed, scaleable process. At the start of the project, the process produced low-quality polymer resins from carpet and textile waste. Since then, there has been significant development such that Ambercycle's PET resins can be produced with high purity from building material and apparel wastes. This is done in a high-yield, scalable fashion.

Currently, work is being done to both increase the breadth of feedstock that the process can take in, as well as scale the known processes to the pilot stages. This will result in a pilot unit that gives Ambercycle the necessary data to scale up to larger processing volumes.

The project has significantly derisked the process technology and also opened up myriad commercial opportunities for Ambercycle to explore and apply the technology to. The implementation of the process at the large scale diverts hundreds of thousands of tons of waste material from the landfill, bringing value to customers in the manufacturing industries with advantaged cost, as well as preserving the environment for generations to come.
